item.title: Some things I've learned about 3D Math and Common sources of confusion
item.description: I am by no means an expert in math, but having worked with linear algebra and math in 3D spaces for years now, I think it could be valuable to share some things that I’ve learned and some common sources of confusion when it comes to working in 3D spaces. At the very least, I can provide some insight into working with 3D maths as a game or game engine developer.

item.title: Not Invented Here
item.description: The California Institute of Technology archived a photograph of Richard Feynman’s blackboard at the time of his death. At the top, Feynman wrote: “What I cannot create, I do not understand.” This is a quote that resonates with me strongly. It’s an idea that John Carmack, founder of id Software and pioneer of computer games, seems to agree with. “There are lots of viable paths through engineering. The path I advocate for is ‘knowledge in depth’ - for knowing things really deeply.

item.title: How to switch Windows App to Console App
item.description: When making a C++ executable on Windows, you have the option of choosing between a Windows app and a Console app. A Windows app is an app with a GUI Window, and a Console app runs in the terminal (e.g. Windows Command Prompt). By switching over a Windows App to a Console App, you will get a command prompt window accompanying your GUI program Window. Linker Option Visual Studio or MSVC C++ Compiler Set the /SUBSYSTEM linker option of the MSVC compiler for your project to CONSOLE.

item.title: Quick Guide to PowerShell
item.description: It’s difficult to find the perfect shell for Windows. There are some decent options out there (e.g. Cmder), but in many ways Microsoft’s own PowerShell (aka PoSh, PwSh, psh) is the best option for Windows. It’s also cross-platform! If you have workflow you are used to with PowerShell, you can have the same workflow regardless of the OS you’re on. PowerShell stands out from other shells available on Windows because it’s more than just a command line for interacting with Windows.
